I made a lead acetate in a solution using kitchen vinegar and lead fishing weights, which is on our channel, in Bruce v Britain playlist, and used it to show a counterfeit substance wasn't DMSA. Did take a week to get a strong solution. Gases are produced, one can smell the sickly sweet past the vinegar, simply from aeration of the bubbles, don't do without a hood ... bubbles mean gas no matter what the titration equations say, some common sense comes into play. Not that I often do chemistry, mine is a blooper reel. I did say it was poison in mine... didn't tell people, "Oh and it tastes like sugar!" even though it's been used to poison people throughout history. False Hellebore tastes like iceberg lettuce, but why tell people? Just on the "Don't ingest that!" list, otherwise Mad Science.

Doesn't need heat, doesn't need stirring, doesn't need special purchases from chemical depots, the simplest thing to make around doesn't even need slow addition of hydrogen peroxide, a couple of weights, vinegar, peroxide, go. ... and wait a week while evaporating, repeat.

Of course, mine's a 5% acetate acid solution, that 50%+ might react violently. Nice does make some nice crystals, by my chemistry is utilitarian.

The bubbles forming at 3:36 are due to the reaction being exothermic. The energy released (in the form of heat) from the reaction of the lead oxide particles and acetic acid causes localized boiling of the water. This is confirmed by observations of the visible steam rising from the top of the solution as well as some condensation of water back on the edge of the beaker.

It's likely that the effervescence you see during the addition of lead (II) oxide to acetic acid is CO2, due to contamination of the PbO by lead carbonate.  Many transition metal oxides and hydroxides react with atmospheric CO2, especially in the presence of traces of water, over time to form their corresponding carbonates.  This is particularly evident with metallic ions having a +1 or +2 oxidation state.

Interesting note!  Lead Acetate can also be used in the analysis of caffeine in tea by UV/VIS spectroscopy.  The lead in the compound complexes with the phenols in the tea and this complex falls out of solution.  The resulting mixture can be centrifuged and decanted.  This allows for concentration analysis without interfering compounds like the phenols, which give tea it's color.

I had a car-battery that had been frozen sitting in a plastic tray for a few hours, so a fairly sized puddle of the electrolyte solution leaked out into the tray. Standard procedure was to neutralize the pH by sprinkling it with Na2CO3 powder until neutralized. I did exactly that with a fair excess of Na2CO3, then observed what looked to be ice forming in the mixture as it fizzed and belched until the excess Na2CO3 absorbed all of the remaining H2SO4.

My question is: Would the crystals that looked like ice possibly have been sugar of lead, since the electrolyte solution was fairly well decomposed within a lead-acid car battery?

Having said that, many people will sometimes find a guilty pleasure in sniffing their own trumps. Again, this is instinctive behavior and is done because you can get information about your health in this way and then subconsciously alter your diet slightly - maybe adding a little extra salt to your fries or overdoing your toast slightly for a little-added carbon without even realising you are doing it - all because you sniffed your own fart. Cool. I made some PbAc years ago for preparing lead dioxide electrodes. Because I was lacking in chemicals I used the following process:
I started with preparing basic copper carbonate by reacting copper sulfate with sodium carbonate. The resulting powder was reacted with cleaning vinegar to produce copper acetate.
Then some lead shavings were added. Due to the electrode potentials of the two metals the lead slowly dissolves into solution while the copper is displaced and precipitates as a fine metal powder. It's actually really cool to watch.

I think the lead oxidized a tiny layer in the small particles oooor (engineering mode on) the transport of mass is harder since the particle is smaller so the boundary layer of transfer is so big reaching the small particle is not very viable, the chemistry you know is based in equilibrium and you assume the mass transfer is in equilibrium though for that perfect nice stage to happen you would need years to happen, in this small home experiments that is not a big problem (89% yield is pretty good) but imagine you are an operator in a giant reactor, then this small transport phenomena start taking a very big toll on the production of the product you want.

So if I were you I'd try larger pellets and once the smaller ones form (because they erode) you filter them, and reuse them in a higher temperature, or even try adding a very very small ammount of soap (a tensoactive might lower the interphase tension and then the boundary layer is a bit smaller and thus the reaction can happen within a lifetime hahaha).

Boundary layer is very hard to solve on your own though Bird actually has a solution on the small particle in a liquid problem solved, I have to look up the page, I haven't checked that problem in a while, and some modification needs to happen since there is a reaction going on.

PD: And that is why chemical engineers are needed (also why both a chemist and a chemical engineer HAVE to work together) v

A tip from one amateur chemist to a real chemist. If you get some kind of very smooth, almost "fatty" tupperwave (usually the cheapest stuff, cause it's got more fatty plastic), you will be able to evaporate the crystals and later on just lift them up, because the plastic trays work like teflon, it doesn't stick. It's done miracles for me, and I would never use anything but cheap fake-tupperware stuff now for my crystallizations, at least if I want to be able to pick my crystals up easily after the water has evaporated.
